tossups.question: Description acceptable. Richard Couturier, one man implicated in this scandal, recruited some associates during a Mardi Gras bead-tossing party. In a related scandal to this one, Simon Marketing unfairly penalized Canada. Despite being involved in this scandal, a mobster who was born Gennaro Colombo appeared in a commercial. "Uncle Jerry" was brought down in Operation Final Answer during this scandal, which is chronicled in a 2020 HBO documentary by (*) Ben Affleck and Matt Damon. It didn’t take place in Britain, but this scandal was exposed the day before the 9/11 attacks and was investigated with a sting operation involving a tie-in with Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?. In this scandal, Dodge Vipers were claimed by Jacksonville residents who got a disproportionate number of winning game pieces. For 10 points, identify this rigged contest at a fast-food franchise whose valuable pieces included Boardwalk.

tossups.question: In 2018, Oded Béjà ("oh-DED BEZH-ah") discovered a new class of these proteins using fosmid clones from Lake Kinneret ("kee-NAIR-et"). Paul Gamlin traced one of these proteins to monostratified "giant" cells that dwarf nearby parasol cells. Karl Deisseroth ("DICE-uh-roth") created bistable "switches" from these proteins and rescued Cnga3-knockout mice by expressing a unitary chloride pump in this family from Natronomonas. Xenopus melanophores contain one of these proteins that colocalizes with PACAP in cells that (*) innervate the suprachiasmatic nucleus. Some of these proteins prefixed with archaeo-, halo-, and channel- are common actuators in optogenetics. In 1993, Richard Henderson solved the structure of a bovine protein in this family, making it the first crystallized GPCR; that one binds an all-trans form of vitamin A. For 10 points, what light-sensitive pigments control visual phototransduction in the retina?
tossups.answer: opsins [accept (bovine) rhodopsins or visual purple; accept retinylidene proteins; prompt on RHO; prompt on photopigments; prompt on GPCRs or G protein-coupled receptors or seven-transmembrane domain receptors or 7TM receptors or G protein-linked receptors or GPLRs or heptahelical receptors or serpentine receptors; accept melanopsin or OPN4; accept channelrhodopsins; accept channelrhodopsins; accept halorhodopsins or eNpHR; accept archaeorhodopsins; accept bacteriorhodopsins; accept microbial rhodopsins; accept heliorhodopsins; accept rhodopsin-like receptors]

tossups.question: After seeing a 1989 exhibit on this artist at P.S. 1, the artist R. H. Quaytman made response works titled "+ x, Chapter 34." Maureen gets a supernatural text message after discovering this artist in the film Personal Shopper. This onetime biological illustrator dictated a 2,000-page manifesto titled Studies of the Life of the Soul. Halina Dyrschka's 2020 film Beyond the Visible features several side-by-side shots of this artist with later painters. This member of The Five embarked on a "great commission" to decorate a building following a (*) séance ("SAY-once"). Symbolic circles feature in her monumental series The Ten Largest. This artist's first major non-objective series was titled The Paintings for the Temple and was painted between 1906 and 1915. For 10 points, a blockbuster 2018 exhibition at the Guggenheim reignited interest in what Swedish pioneer of abstract art?
tossups.answer: Hilma af Klint [accept Hilma af Klint: Paintings for the Future]

tossups.question: A Pizza Hut billboard in this city advertising "Gigabites of Taste" gave Thomas Friedman the idea to write The World is Flat. This city's most prominent causeway, Sarjapur Road, is frequently afflicted by toxic smoke, and its largest lake, Bellandur, regularly catches fire. This city's dominant industry includes the headquarters of Wipro and is congregated in the neighborhood of Whitefield. It’s not in Africa, but this city's moderate temperatures are a result of being (*) 3,000 feet above sea level, so most of its water must be pumped 900 feet up from the Cauvery River. The NGO Friends of Lakes is attempting to build a million recharge wells in this inland city to combat its severe water crisis. This city is the headquarters of the consulting and outsourcing company Infosys. For 10 points, name this city known as India's Silicon Valley, the capital of Karnataka.
tossups.answer: Bangalore [or Bengaluru]

tossups.question: Over one thousand people were interviewed about the effects of this practice by social psychologist Craig Haney. Anthony Kennedy cited the case of Kalief Browder in his opinion criticizing this practice in a 2015 case involving Hector Ayala. Albert Woodfox wrote a memoir titled for this type of practice, which is ostensibly banned by Canada's Bill C-83. A 2018 document by Yale's Liman Center concluded that 61,000 Americans were subject to this practice, with about 2,000 of them having it applied for at least 6 months. The UN definition of this policy includes (*) lasting more than 22 hours per day. A 2013 hunger strike in California that started at a facility in Pelican Bay sought to end this practice, which is often carried out in "the hole." For 10 points, name this type of punishment where a prisoner is denied any "meaningful human contact" for extended periods.
tossups.answer: solitary confinement [or prison segregation; or isolation; prompt on imprisonment or confinement or torture; prompt on being sent to the hole before mentioned; accept Solitary: Unbroken by Four Decades in Solitary Confinement. My Story of Transformation and Hope]

tossups.question: One of this composer's settings of psalms commemorates the Armenian Genocide and is titled Psalmus No. 3. In 2012, this composer wrote the last of three pieces inspired by Lucretius titled De Natura Sonoris. Another piece by this composer accompanies a long shot of a shootout in a refugee camp near the end of Alfonso Cuarón's film Children of Men. He included a vernacular rendition of the Trisagion and a concluding Libera Animas movement in his setting of the requiem mass, to which he added a Ciaconna ("chah-KON-nah") after the 2005 death of (*) John Paul II. In Twin Peaks: The Return, an explosion is accompanied by this composer's most iconic piece, which opens with the successive entrance of groups of 52 string players on harsh, vibrating high notes. For 10 points, name this recently-deceased composer of Polish Requiem and Threnody for the Victims of Hiroshima.
tossups.answer: Krzysztof Penderecki ("k’SHISH-toff pen-duh-RETS-kee")

tossups.question: A character in one book by this author describes how the fire of burning wheat fields "carried the childhood smell of bread into the air"; elsewhere in that book, this author recounts children spreading heroin each night in camps. Another book by this author closes with a speech from the wife of a liquidator who was responsible for burying huge amounts of topsoil. This author found "what I heard in childhood" in three other authors’ book I Am from a Burning Village, inspiring her signature technique. The title of one work by this author comes from the caskets used to (*) ship back dead soldiers from Afghanistan. In 1992, she was sued for libel for writing Zinky Boys, which like many of her works was built from hundreds of interviews. For 10 points, name this author of Voices of Chernobyl, a Belarussian oral historian and winner of the 2015 Nobel Prize in Literature.
tossups.answer: Svetlana Alexievich [or Svetlana Alexandrovna Alexievich]

tossups.question: Economists Daron Acemoğlu ("dah-ROAN ah-jay-MOH-loo") and Joshua D. Angrist found that employment drops due to this legislation were most pronounced for men at mid-sized firms. Cruise ships flying foreign flags were ruled to be subject to this legislation in the 2005 Spector case. A Higher Ground Productions documentary that was released on the 30th anniversary of this legislation featured clips of people such as Judy Heumann attending Camp Jened. A 2008 amendment to this legislation chided the Supreme Court for misinterpreting the definition of "major (*) life activity" in Toyota v. Williams. In 2019, the Supreme Court declined to address whether this law applied to the website for Domino's Pizza. A "Capitol Crawl" pushed for this legislation during the George H. W. Bush administration. For 10 points, name this 1990 legislation that mandated things like wheelchair ramps in many commercial stores.
tossups.answer: Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 [or ADA] (The documentary is Crip Camp: A Disability Revolution.)
tossups.metadata: The documentary is Crip Camp: A Disability Revolution.

tossups.question: On a show with this title, Carrie Mae Weems gives a pep talk to the protagonist at an art colony on Martha's Vineyard, where she hooks up with a Chris Ofili stand-in and fails to expel a white donor who speaks in AAVE, in the episode "#NationTime." A show and movie with this title both show album covers after playing songs. A film with this title begins with the protagonist reading the opening of Their Eyes Were Watching God on her giant bed. (*) DeWanda Wise stars in a show with this title, whose theme song "Where Brooklyn At?" reflects its setting in Fort Green. An earlier black-and-white film with this title stars Tracy Camilla Johns as a woman maintaining competing relationships with Jamie Overstreet, Greer Childs, and Mars Blackmon. For 10 points, give this shared title of a breakout 1986 film and a recent TV series about Nola Darling, directed by Spike Lee.
tossups.answer: She's Gotta Have It

tossups.question: A story by this author imagined the Pentagon sending him to disarm a nuclear warhead in Tulsa. This author and Linda LaScola collected interviews for The Clergy Project in Caught in the Pulpit. This thinker's cybernetic dog Tati appears on the cover of his 1998 essay collection discussing Julian Jaynes; in the 1990s, he worked with MIT researchers to create the humanoid robot Cog. This author of "Where Am I?" argued that "billions of years of irreplaceable (*) design work" were prerequisites for Bach's St. Matthew Passion. This author of Brainchildren divided human interactions with objects into physicalist, design, and intentional stances. This New Atheist "horseman" defended Turing's gradualism, dismissing the "Zombic hunch." John Searle's Chinese room inspired this thinker to outline "fables" called "intuition pumps." For 10 points, who wrote Darwin's Dangerous Idea?
tossups.answer: Daniel Dennett [or Daniel Clement Dennett III]

During this conflict, one government widely distributed set-top boxes capable of tuning into the pirate beoutQ ("Be-Out-Q") TV network. A proxy fight in this conflict centered on the takeover of the Newcastle United football team. During this conflict, four cargo planes filled with food were sent by Iran to relieve a food shortage brought on by the closure of one country's only land crossing. tossups.question: It’s unrelated to accounting, but Article 26 of this legislation outlines the responsibilities in "joint controller" situations. Ben Thompson has argued that the "fundamentalism" represented in this law has strengthened large incumbent firms. A company called Klout claimed that this legislation drove it to bankruptcy. Lawyers have argued over the difference between this legislation's terms "consent" and "explicit consent." Mas Schrems founded NOYB to launch lawsuits for violations of this legislation, which can result in a fine of 4% of annual revenue. By the terms of this legislation, (*) breaches must be reported within 72 hours. California's CCPA was modeled on this non-American law, which mandates that "specific" and "unambiguous" reasons must be given for collection of information. For 10 points, name this EU privacy regulation.
tossups.answer: GDPR [or General Data Protection Regulation]

tossups.question: Hilton Als compared this character to a similar one who visits David Jackson and James Merrill in the second part of "The Changing Light at Sandover." In one scene, this character commands another to dig under sink tiles. In a YouTube video, Gwen Hales and Finn Caldwell describe how counterweighting was used to bring this character to life for a revival. This character was played by Amanda Lawrence and a team of shadows in a 2018 production starring Nathan Lane and (*) Andrew Garfield. The actor playing this character also plays Emily, a nurse. This character proclaims, "the great work begins." A man who has a wet dream about this character phones up Belize to talk about the dream; this character also briefly has sex with Prior Walter. tossups.question: Crackdowns on opium have left this good as the main product of Thailand's Akha people. After a 1999 protest at Georgetown, economist Pietra Rivoli spent five years tracing the origins of a product made from this good in Texas and China. In 2012, India caused a market panic by briefly banning exports of this good from its chief producers Maharashtra ("ma-ha-RAHSH-truh") and Gujarat ("goo-juh-RAHT"). In 2014, the WTO settled a long-running dispute about US subsidies for this good with a 300-million-dollar payment to Brazilian (*) farmers. ICAC regulates this chief export of Benin. Public sector workers are still forced to harvest this crop in Uzbekistan, where its Soviet-era production drained the Aral Sea. Sven Beckert's Bancroft-winning history of this crop's "empire" argues that "war capitalism" was key to boosting its yields in Egypt during the US Civil War. tossups.question: A 2018 book by this author argues that the United States stoked resentment by promoting capitalism in Vietnam, since 70 to 80% of the wealth belonged to the hated Chinese "market-dominant minority;" in that book, she analyzed Afghanistan using group dynamics. A book by this author and her husband notes that the Mormon church owns "10 times more Florida real estate than… Disney" and celebrates virtues like insecurity and impulse control in (*) Nigerian-Americans and Cuban exiles. This author of Political Tribes allegedly groomed women to clerk for Brett Kavanaugh at Yale Law. With her husband, accused sexual harasser Jed Rubenfeld, she wrote The Triple Package. This author's hit memoir outlined her rules banning sleepovers and mandating piano and violin practice for her two daughters to get ahead of "Western" parents. For 10 points, name this author of Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother.

tossups.question: A man who excels in this activity named Jason Goodyear gets arrested for vandalizing Taliesin West in the opening section of a 2020 novel by Paris Review editor Emily Nemens. Excellence in this activity allows a girl named Gwen to gain entrance to the privileged Netted class in a dystopian future divided into countries like ChinRussia and AutoAmerica in Gish Jen's novel The Resisters. A novel centering on this activity at a Melville-obsessed college in Wisconsin features a character named Owen Dunne who suddenly loses his skills at it. Henry Skrimshander is the protagonist of a novel about this sport by (*) Chad Harbach. J. Edgar Hoover watches this sport in a 1951 game that opens a novel about Nick Shay, Don DeLillo's Underworld. tossups.question: A 2021 book titled for one of these things examines “Lanchester’s paradox,” arguing that we’ve entered a stage that requires a “need for militancy.” That book about “blowing up” one of these things was written by Andreas Malm. In 1998, a poorly-maintained one of these things resulted in the death of over a thousand people in Jesse, Nigeria. Before being arrested in 2020, a man known as “The Sledgehammer” specialized in stealing from these things in the “red triangle.” Criminals known as (*) huachicoleros ("wa-chee-co-LAIR-ohs") specialize in stealing from these things; in January 2019, 137 people were killed while attempting to steal from one in the Mexican town of Tlahuelilpan ("tla-way-LEEL-pahn"). Cartel-controlled theft from these things supposedly accounts for 3 billion dollars a year in lost revenue for Pemex. For 10 points, name these structures that transport fossil fuels.

In 2019, campus advocates protesting this organization staged sit-ins to get Hillel to disaffiliate with it. The young adults who participate in this program usually make a stop at the Dead Sea. parts: Identify this debut novel by Téa Obreht, titled for a deaf-mute who is rumored to have had a child with the title creature during World War II.
The Tiger's Wife is set in a fictional version of this Communist former country. The long and bloody breakup of this country was chronicled in Steven Galloway's novel The Cellist of Sarajevo.

Obreht's follow-up to The Tiger's Wife was Inland, a novel in this genre that unusually features a Muslim protagonist named Lurie Mattie. A man with no arms or legs recites from "Ozymandias" in a short from a 2018 anthology film in this genre.

Andrey Guryev, who made his fortune selling this good, built a massive basement for Witanhurst, his London mansion. The Haber–Bosch process produces nitrogen-based versions of this good, which is a major source of urea pollution in rural waterways.
This district in Inner London granted no new permits for iceberg basements in 2017 or 2018. This district's Angel Tube Station has the longest escalator in the London Underground system.

parts: Name these people, some 1 million of whom have moved to a certain city in recent decades through a one-way permit system. They're often told to "correct their accent" even if they already speak Cantonese. Description acceptable.

Peaceful "wo lei fei" in Hong Kong often participate in protests by performing this action. A controversial law passed in June 2020 made it a crime to lodge "insults" when this action was taking place in Hong Kong.

Tensions between Hong Kongers and mainlanders escalated in 2014 when a mainlander was filmed performing this action. Rajasthan health minister Kalicharan Saraf was photographed performing this action despite a BJP campaign to stamp it out.

bonuses.leadin: The subject of this event receives cage-fighting lessons and repeatedly attempts to get his Bic cigarette lighter back. For 10 points each:
answers: the kidnapping of Michel Houellebecq ("well-BECK") [or L'enlèvement de Michel Houellebecq; or equivalents]
The Map and the Territory [or La carte et le territoire]
al-Qaeda [or al-Qa'ida]
parts: Identify this event, the subject of a 2014 comedy film by Guillaume Nicloux ("ghee-YOME nee-CLOO"). Its central author spends the film drinking and debating the filmmakers about his own biography of H. P. Lovecraft and what he calls the "concentration camp" architecture of Le Corbusier.

The movie is based on a 2011 incident in which Houellebecq went missing while promoting this 2010 novel, for which he won the Prix Goncourt. This novel involves a fictionalized murder of Houellebecq himself.
Some rumors held that Houellebecq had been kidnapped by this terrorist group, whose leader was killed in a raid in Abbottabad in 2011.
answers_formatted: The Map and the Territory [or La carte et le territoire]

bonuses.leadin: Tim Spector led a "British" version of this project, which collaborated with Jeff Leach's "Human Food Project" before he was indicted for sexual assault. For 10 points each:
answers: American Gut Project [or AGP; accept British Gut Project or BGP]
Venezuela [or Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela; or República Bolivariana de Venezuela]
C-sections [or Caesarean births; or elective C-sections]
parts: Name this citizen science project that collected thousands of human microbiome samples. Rob Knight's lab at UCSD led this project, which sought to identify the composition of the "Western" microbiota.
American Gut Project samples are often compared with those of the Guahibo people in this country, where María Dominguez-Bello profiled the Yanomami microbiome near Puerto Ayacucho.

Dominguez-Bello used Venezuelan data to argue that this procedure drastically alters microbiome composition, inspiring a fad for "vaginal seeding." Over half of all Brazilian mothers opt for this procedure.
answers_formatted: American Gut Project [or AGP; accept British Gut Project or BGP]
Venezuela [or Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela; or República Bolivariana de Venezuela]

parts: Identify these places that often contain Cordyline. A book by Helen Leach traces the thousand-year history of these places, which are often made with kō sticks. Description acceptable.
Māori gardens have historically centered on the kūmara variety of this starchy staple vegetable that is now popular with bodybuilders. Thanksgiving recipes often candy these root vegetables.

Roasted sweet potatoes, or "goguma," are a common street food in this national cuisine, which also prepares sweet potato starch to resemble "glass." Single people eat dishes made with a black bean paste on this country's "Black Day."

bonuses.leadin: Stephen Montgomery's GWAS ("G-woss") studies on Sardinians have not found a life-extending genetic variant to explain these places. For 10 points each:
answers: Blue Zones
happiness [or being happy or equivalents; accept Gross National Happiness or GNH; accept The Blue Zones of Happiness]
Seventh-day Adventists [prompt on Protestants or Christians]
parts: Name these alleged hotspots of longevity that include Okinawa and Costa Rica's Nicoya Peninsula. A 2019 preprint argues that these places are really just hotspots of poor birth records.

Dan Buettner conceived the Blue Zones and extended them to hotspots of this concept in Mexico, Denmark, and Singapore. Positive psychology studies this concept, which Bhutan famously measures as a Gross National characteristic.

Surprisingly, one of the Blue Zones is located in the US city of Loma Linda, where many people follow this religion. In 2005, they added "Growing in Christ" to their 27 Fundamental Beliefs to make 28.
answers_formatted: happiness [or being happy or equivalents; accept Gross National Happiness or GNH; accept The Blue Zones of Happiness]

bonuses.leadin: Glenn Adamson wrote a defense of the "progressive" form of this practice to diversify collections, whose regular form was opposed by many art professionals in a letter addressed to the di Rosa Foundation. For 10 points each:
answers: deaccessioning [or word forms]
Wayne Thiebaud ("TEE-boh")
Jackson Pollock [or Paul Jackson Pollock]
parts: Give this specific term for a practice that the Association of Art Museum Directors requires "not be used for operations or capital expenses."

Among the signatories of the di Rosa letter was this artist, who at age 99 contributed a painting of an ice cream cone titled Double Scoop for a New Yorker cover in 2020. He’s known for painting confections.

In September 2020, Syracuse's Everson Museum of Art announced that it would deaccession this Abstract Expressionist's 1946 painting Red Composition. In a 2000 biopic, Marcia Gay Harden played his wife, the painter Lee Krasner.

bonuses.leadin: This idea requires sustaining a small "bubble" around a spaceship within which the vacuum energy density is negative. For 10 points each:
answers: Alcubierre ("ahl-koo-BYAIR-ay") warp drive [or Alcubierre metric; or Alcubierre drive; prompt on warp drive]
time dilation [prompt on dilation]
Casimir effect [accept Casimir force; prompt on van der Waals forces, as one theory holds that it's a variety of them]
parts: Name this solution to Einstein's field equations, proposed by an eponymous Mexican physicist, which would theoretically allow faster-than-light travel without violating special relativity.

Thanks to this effect predicted by special relativity, a spaceship using an Alcubierre warp drive could make it to Alpha Centauri in weeks, though for an outside observer it would look like thousands of years.

Alcubierre suggested sustaining a negative energy density with this effect, first physically observed in 1997. Quantum electrodynamics explains this weak, long-range attraction as a result of induced vacuum fluctuations.
answers_formatted: Casimir effect [accept Casimir force; prompt on van der Waals forces, as one theory holds that it's a variety of them]
promptable: van der Waals forces, as one theory holds that it's a variety of them

parts: Identify this occupation. Loadsmart and the now-defunct Starsky Robotics were startups trying to automate these people out of a job.

Truck drivers in this state were glorified in a reality series produced by Thom Beers, who had earlier found success glamorizing the life of king crab fishermen departing from this state's port of Dutch Harbor on another reality show.
A much-hated rule that came into effect in 2016 required truckers to use these devices, which replaced paper books, to record miles traveled and hours driven.

money [prompt on related answers like credit or banking by asking "what is the title word?"; accept The Ascent of Money: A Financial History of the World; accept money supply or money stock]

parts: Name this book that advances similar arguments to its author’s A Game as Old as Empire. This 2004 John Perkins book alleges that firms like Chas. T. Main preyed upon developing countries by overstating the benefits of GDP growth.

Niall Ferguson criticized Confessions of an Economic Hit Man in his 2008 history of this stuff's "ascent." Ricardo Lagos distinguished "inside" and "outside" types of this stuff, whose optimal level was determined by Thomas J. Sargent.

Money is used to measure the liquidated "financial" type of this factor of production, which does not flow to developing countries according to the "Lucas paradox." The WEF and World Bank now track its "human" form.
answers_formatted: money [prompt on related answers like credit or banking by asking "what is the title word?; accept The Ascent of Money: A Financial History of the World; accept money supply or money stock]

Transparent
Marfa
parts: Identify this co-owner of topplethepatriarchy.com and founder of Wifey.tv who, with Sarah Gubbins, adapted the novel I Love Dick for television.
Soloway is best known for creating this TV show, whose early seasons featured Jeffrey Tambor's character transitioning to become Maura Pfefferman.
Soloway's adaptation of I Love Dick is set in this Texas artists' colony. Minimalist works by Donald Judd in this town have attracted gentrifiers who are raising taxes for its poor Latino residents.

Nell Zink lives in this country, where North African refugees set up a protest camp in Jenny Erpenbeck's Go, Went, Gone. Franzen's Purity is partly set during an era when Stasi agents spied on this country's citizens.

An event from this play names a very long novel by German author Arno Schmidt. The Discworld novel Lords and Ladies parodies this play, which is the signature play of the University of Michigan's Shakespeare in the Arb.

parts: Identify this man who gave the controversial "Confusing God and Government" sermon at the Trinity United Church of Christ in 2003.
This three-word phrase coined by Jeremiah Wright was used to title Barack Obama's 2006 follow-up to his book Dreams from My Father.
More recently, Wright has appeared in attack ads against Raphael Warnock, a pastor at this church in Atlanta where both Martin Luther King Sr. and Jr. were pastors.
